column4: You are trying to remount /home elsewhere or just to umount it ?
I dont know this is all becoming too complicated. you see im trying to recreate the DellUtility partition (I thought I only needed the DellRestore partition)
genii I am trying to restore my system to its factory settings but I need to recreate a Utility partition that was on here before..
genii i have too many partitions to recreate it. however the space which the partition used before is still there.. untouched its just no longer a partition anymore

Because if you are just trying to remount it elsewhere, you can do that with something like edit fstab to the new mountpoint, then: (sudo) mount -o remount /devname        (not /mountname since it is different after editing the fstab)
genii actually i was trying to make it so i only have a / partition. i dont want my /home partition anymore
genii i want it reallocated into /
Ah. For that you'l have to tinker from livecd then, or Recovery mode since root's home is not in /home but in /root

genii i see. any ideas for this unallocated space.. presumably it still has all the files I need there. its just not a partition anymore... if i create it as say a fat16 partition would the files formerly there return?
Recovering the files on it will be possible if you have not deleted the partition or resized it. eg: the only change was to change the partition type or just umount it
If you deleted the original then resized it not much hope
genii the partition no longer exists. it is unallocated space
Then there is not much hope of files recovery
Wait. Unallocated... but did you resize it?

Something to try as a last resort:  at Terminal run: sudo fdisk /dev/<the drive name here>       eg: sda3   or whatever used to be the /home    then t to change partition tye. Put in 83 for type. then w  to write changes. then see if you can manually mount it
